subsection.name: 4.5 Cayenne DataSource
subsection.p:
Cayenne is designed to work with any javax.sql.DataSource implementation. When Cayenne applications are deployed in containers (Web, EJB, etc.), DataSource would normally be obtained from the container (see deployment section).
However Cayenne provides full implementation of DataSource functionality of it own, including connection pooling. This allows to deploy standalone Cayenne applications, as well as to use containers that don't supports JNDI DataSource mapping. Cayenne DataSource can also be used as a container-provided DataSource, even when the main part of the Cayenne functionality is not used. For example it can be used as a DataSource implementation of Tomcat web container. (For a sample configuration follow this link, then scroll down to the sample server.xml configuration file.)

Cayenne DataSource is implemented in org.objectstyle.cayenne.conn package. The following class diagram shows how Cayenne connection package classes (shown in light blue) implement java.sql and javax.sql interfaces (shown in yellow) to provide DataSource with connection pooling.

Normally instances of PoolManager class serve as a publicly accessible DataSource objects. They use PoolDataSource internally as a factory of PooledConnections. Each PooledConnectionImpl produces a JDBC Connection object that is used to connect to the database. JDBC Connections are returned to the user as ConnectionWrapper objects that delegate all database operations to the underlying connection and notify parent PooledConnection about SQLExceptions.
